This is a classic example of a logical fallacy known as affirming the consequent. The statement "If Ben ate pasta, then Kate ate salad" is a conditional statement that implies a causal relationship between Ben eating pasta and Kate eating salad. However, the statement does not necessarily imply that the opposite is true, i.e., that if Ben did not eat pasta, then Kate did not eat salad.

To see why this is the case, consider the possibility that Ben ate pasta but Kate did not eat salad. This does not necessarily mean that Ben did not eat pasta, as Kate may have eaten something else instead. Therefore, the statement "If Ben ate pasta, then Kate ate salad" does not logically entail the statement "If Ben did not eat pasta, then Kate did not eat salad."
